metadata.case_name: Commissioner of Income-tax v. Respondent Company
metadata.case_number: Appeal from Income-tax Reference No. 116 of 1960

facts.text: Relevant assessment year is 1950-51 and the respondent company's previous year ended on March 31, 1950.

Income-tax Officer made an order dated March 15, 1956, under section 23A(1) of the Income-tax Act, 1922, holding that Rs. 35,476 should be deemed as having been distributed as dividend by the respondent and proportionate share included in shareholders' total income.
Balance-sheet of the respondent disclosed past losses amounting to Rs. 45,692 brought forward.

Income-tax Officer held past losses resulted from failure in properly accounting for bonus shares received by respondent; recomputed losses of earlier years by valuing bonus shares at nil, holding losses at Rs. 6,509; recomputation by disallowing Rs. 37,500 from debits in share account (cost of bonus shares at face value) and adding Rs. 10,151 on account of grossing up of dividends and interest on securities.

Respondent appealed to Appellate Assistant Commissioner, who by order dated May 11, 1957, cancelled ITO's order under section 23A; held losses Rs. 6,509, income-tax chargeable Rs. 17,829, subscribed capital Rs. 6,00,000; profits not adequate for section 23A.

Commissioner of Income-tax appealed to Appellate Tribunal, which set aside AAC order, restored ITO order under section 23A; agreed past losses Rs. 6,509; held AAC wrong in not considering actual tax liability Rs. 17,829 and in using subscribed and paid-up capital for comparing with profits.

Under section 66(1) of the Act, Appellate Tribunal referred two questions to High Court: (1) Whether profits made by applicant in year of account did not attract section 23A(1)? (2) Whether tax liability Rs. 17,829 should be taken into consideration for determining order under section 23A(1)?

Calcutta High Court by judgment dated March 10, 1964, answered first question in negative; second question also negative as conceded by counsel for respondent that AAC should not have taken tax liability into consideration.

legal_issues.text: Whether, on the facts and in the circumstances of the case, the profits made by the applicant in the year of account did not attract the application of section 23A(1)?

Whether, on the facts and in the circumstances of the case, the tax liability for the assessment year under consideration, amounting to Rs. 17,829 should be taken into consideration for the purpose of determining whether an order under section 23A(1) should be made on the applicant?

Whether the High Court was right in holding that the bonus shares should have been valued at their face value and the loss of Rs. 35,000 on the valuation of the shares as such should have been considered in determining the applicability of section 23A.

petitioner_arguments.text: The view expressed by the High Court must be taken to have been impliedly overruled by the judgment of this Court in Commissioner of Income-tax v. Dalmia Investment Co. Ltd.; there had to be recomputation of the value of the bonus shares on the principle enunciated in that case.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Commissioner of Income-tax v. Dalmia Investment Co. Ltd.

respondent_arguments.text: Conceded by counsel on behalf of the respondent that the Appellate Assistant Commissioner should not have taken into consideration the tax liability of Rs. 17,829 for finding no fund available for payment of dividend.

court_reasoning.text: In Commissioner of Income-tax v. Dalmia Investment Co. Ltd., this Court held that when bonus shares are issued in respect of ordinary shares held by an assessee, their real cost cannot be taken to be nil or their face value; proper method is to spread the cost of the old shares over old shares and new issue (bonus shares) if they rank pari passu, or adjust price proportionately or on equitable considerations based on market price.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Question of application of section 23A(1) must be decided after recomputation of the value of the bonus shares on the basis of the principle in Dalmia Investment.

holdings.text: Bonus shares real cost to assessee cannot be nil or face value; value by spreading cost of old shares over old and new shares if pari passu, or adjust proportionately or equitably.

precedents_cited.case_name: Commissioner of Income-tax v. Dalmia Investment Co. Ltd.
precedents_cited.relevance: Principle for valuation of bonus shares for recomputing past losses to determine section 23A applicability.

statutes_cited.name: Income-tax Act, 1922
statutes_cited.relevance: ITO order deeming dividend under 23A(1); Tribunal reference under 66(1); determination of applicability of 23A(1) after recomputing losses.

outcome.summary: Appeal allowed; judgment of High Court dated March 10, 1964 set aside; High Court directed to rehear the reference keeping in view the principle laid down in Commissioner of Income-tax v. Dalmia Investment Co. Ltd.
outcome.relief_granted: Remit to High Court for rehearing on bonus shares valuation.

key_quotes.text: "the real cost to the assessee cannot be taken to be nil or their face value. The proper method of valuation is to spread the cost of the old shares over the old shares and the new issue viz., the bonus shares taken together if they rank pari passu"
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core principle from Dalmia case applied to bonus shares valuation for section 23A.

key_quotes.text: "It is manifest that the question of application of section 23A(1) of the Act must be decided after recomputation of the value of the bonus share on the basis of the principle expressed by this Court in Commissioner of Income-tax v. Dalmia Investment Co. Ltd."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Directs basis for High Court rehearing.
